intro: Heteromeles salicifolia, commonly known as the coast live oak, is a deciduous tree native to coastal regions of California and southern Oregon. It has lance-shaped leaves that are typically 2–6 inches long and have a leathery texture. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in the spring, followed by red, fleshy fruits that are edible for certain wildlife. Its bark is thick and fissured, providing habitat for various insects and birds. This plant plays an important role in local ecosystems and is often found in chaparral and coastal scrub habitats.
